comments.author: Manggy
comments.content:
Yeah, I was about to write about the non-meatiness of Ba-cos but you already mentioned it :)
I wish I could get my hands on some farro. I tried to look for some but could only find cracked bulghur, which looked messy (I wanted whole grains, they look better in pictures). I ended up buying couscous, which is a real disappointment.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I can imagine farro might be hard to find in Manila. If you are desperate enough you can buy it on Amazon.

comments.author: bri
comments.content: Hmmm...Bacon Salt, huh?  My husband was just saying the other day that he wished there was a vegetarian version of bacon.  Not too thrilled about the artificial flavoring aspect, but maybe a little bit isn't too bad.  We use all these other substitutions (capers for anchovies, tofu/mushrooms/cheese for meat), so maybe I'll have to give Bacon Salt a chance.  Just gotta see how bad the ingredients are first.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Bri! You know what else is a good sub for anchovies in sauces that are pureed? Arame seaweed, soaked and then ground. It has that very good taste of the sea. (Got this trick from Cafe Flora!).

comments.author: bri
comments.content: Thanks, Michael.  I don't think I've ever worked with arame before, so I'll check it out.  I wouldn't normally think of using a so-called Japanese ingredient in Italian food, but hey, do the Japanese have a corner on the ocean? :)

comments.author: Marissa
comments.content:
The Hickory is my absolute favorite flavor...I sautee some kale with it, add shiitake mushrooms and them some balsamic vinegar...oh and a glove of garlic

*swoon*

I adore the bacon salt, it's my favorite condiment!

comments.author: Seattle Suz
comments.content: The hickory flavor is vegan and all are kosher.  These are local boys and I'm thrilled to use their products- like a kid with a new toy.

comments.author: lauren
comments.content: Since this post, btw, the Bacon Salt folks have come out with a natural version that can be found in Whole Foods... no MSG!

comments.author: Tisha
comments.content: I have also heard that smoked garlic gives a good substitute for bacon.  I have not tried it yet.

comments.author: susan
comments.content:
try FAKIN BACON BITS by Frontier for great flavor added to collards or any greens.  i add them to beans as well.   have not seen bacon salt, but not crazy
about "artificial ingredients".

comments.author: Angie B
comments.content: Fabulous! I added blanched beet greens and roasted golden beets, YUM!
